description: Origin unknown; the spelling may have been influenced by the unrelated word syllable.

entries.meaning: A drink dating back to the 16th century consisting primarily of milk curdled with an alcoholic beverage or some acid such as lemon juice, which is usually then sweetened and spiced. [from 16th c.]
Also everlasting syllabub or solid syllabub: a dessert pudding derived from the drink. [from 16th c.]
examples: Mother by hys sonne he hathe sende me a letter / Promysynge hereafter to be to vs better / And you and I with my greate clubbe / Muste walke to him and eate a solybubbe / and we shall make merye / and synge tyrle on the berye  [â€¦]

entries.meaning: (dated, figuratively) Something lacking substance; something frothy, insubstantial, or lightweight.
